content: Hello everyone, welcome to the session where we will be covering inferential statistics.
This is the last session for this self-paced statistics and probability hands on.
And so let's take a look at the agenda for the session.
First of all, we are going to discuss what exactly is inferential statistics and how it is
used in the science.
And then we are going to discuss confidence interval.
Following further, we are going to take a look at what exactly is hypothesis testing,
the various types of errors that we have in hypothesis testing.
And after that, we will be taking a look at t test, f test, z test and chi square test.
And finally, we will be ending up this session with ANOVA.
So without any further ado, let's understand what is inferential statistics.
So the trial descriptive statistics describes the data.
inferential statistics is used to draw conclusions about the population based on statistical findings
on sample analysis.
So this has a very simple meaning.
We have a sample taken from a population.
Now if you want to draw conclusions about the population, we will perform some sort of
statistical test and then we will create inferences based on the findings.
So that is what inferential statistics is all about.
Now moving further, let's try to understand what exactly is confidence interval.
Confidence interval assumes certainty of population parameter falling in the given intervals.
The intervals could be 95% or 99% or so.
Normally in most of the problems, we take intervals as 95%.
The alpha value will be 0.05% for that.
We will be covering that later on in the session.
To understand confidence in the will, let's take a very simple example.
So if a point estimate 10.0 from the sample statistics for the confidence in double 95
percent falls into 9.5 to 10.5, then we can infer that there is a 95% certainty that the
true or population estimate will fall in the same interval.
Now to understand this, let's say for a sample, we have calculated the confidence in
double which is 9.5 to 10.5.
And a point estimated for example is mean of the sample is 10.0.
So we can conclude or we can take an inference that if we take the population mean, it is
going to fall in this particular interval and the certainty of happening that particular
event is going to be 95%.
So that is how we can understand confidence in double.
Now to plot or basically implement confidence in double, we have taken a small snippet over
here which we have implemented using Python programming.
We have taken a random normal samples of size 100 and calculated the lower confidence
in double and upper confidence in double with the interval value of 95%.
Now if you take a look at the snippet over here, to calculate the confidence interval,
we have taken the sample mean, the sample standard deviation and the standard error.
So these things are very important when you are taking confidence in double for any
sample.
And then we have calculated the Z value as well which is nothing but the Z score where
we would the sample mean and the standard deviation divided from the value itself.
And using that Z value and the standard error, we have basically computed lower confidence
in double and upper count difference in double.
If you take a look at the example I was talking about earlier, the lower CIO is 9.5 and
the upper CIO is 10.5.
Now using those lower CIO and upper CIO, we can plot the confidence in double over here
and that is basically saying or telling us the sample mean is falling within this particular
interval that we have calculated the lower CIO and the upper CIO.
Now according to our analysis, we can certainly say that there is a 95% certainty that the
population mean will also be in the given interval because we have done the same thing
on the sample.
So that is how confidence in double works and we can create inferences based on this.
And this was a very simple implementation using Python programming and we have normally
used sci-fi for statistics and statistics module as well to calculate the sample standard
deviation.
And to plot this, we have used the display that can be used using matplotlib or C-bone.
So now that we are done with confidence interval, let us move on and discuss hypothesis testing.
So hypothesis testing is the analysis where the possibility of an assumption for a population
parameter is tested on the sample and statistical evidence is used to verify the hypothesis.
So I will give you a very simple example here.
So whenever we are working on a time series data, if you are using an REMA or a Syrimax
model, that is seasonal REMA, we have to be certain that the time series data that we
are going to analyze is stationary or not, you know, a test of stationarity where we use
the AD fuller method.
Now in the AD fuller method, what we test is if our data is stationary or not.
Now that particular test gives us this test statistic and the p value.
So based on the p value, we reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis.
So what it actually means is using a statistical test that is I am performing on any sample,
I can give an inference, you know, within evidence that is backed by evidence or you know,
statistical finding that I have done from the test that will negate or accept some kind
of hypothesis that I have given to that particular problem.
That we will cover later on the session when we are performing a test sample test for means
and sample test for proportions and test of independence.
The example that I have given you is a little advanced one, whenever you are working on
a time series, you will be using that.
Now talking about the steps involving hypothesis testing.
So the first one is you have to formulate two hypothesis for your analysis.
The first one is going to be the null hypothesis and the other one will be the alternate hypothesis
and based on your findings, you have to reject or fail to reject your null hypothesis.
The second step is drawing samples from population for analysis.
So this has to be very efficient, you know, in a way where you have to be very certain
of how you are doing your sampling for your analysis.
You know, most of these tests that we do for sample means we need a random sampling, you
know, that we have discussed in one of the sessions where we are using sampling techniques.
So the sample has to be random taken independently and that we have to figure out before doing
any of the tests.
That is also very important step when we are performing hypothesis testing.
After that we have to perform appropriate statistical test.
For example, samples that are less in number, let's say less than 30 or 30, we will be
using or T test for means, but if samples are more than that, then we move on to Z test.
So that is one of the difference, you know, one of the basic points which we have to consider.
For each test, we have to keep in consideration what kind of data we are analyzing or
what kind of result that we are seeking.
And last but not least, there is a step where we are accepting basically in statistical terms
we do not say accept, we always say fail to reject or reject the hypothesis based on the
evidence.
That is our any test statistic and the p value.
p value basically is nothing but let's say if I have taken the alpha value as 0.05 and
if it does not fall under that, I can say with certainty that the statistical finding is
not going to support hypothesis because that's what the p value says.
So now that we are done with the the steps involved hypothesis testing, let's take a look
at what exactly is the null hypothesis and what exactly is alternate hypothesis.
So null hypothesis states that there is no effect on the population mean.
Certainly or in most of the time whenever we are taking null hypothesis, we go with the
statements like it does not have any effect, the sample means are the same.
Or if we have to, you know, give any other alternate hypothesis, we basically go with statements
like there is going to be an effect on population mean or the population means are not similar.
So that is how we formulate the null hypothesis and the alternate hypothesis.
There is just one example that we can have for null and I alternate hypothesis and when
we are talking about errors in hypothesis testing, there are type 1 error and type 2 error.
Type 1 error is the false positive error where we have rejected the null hypothesis but it
is indeed actually true and type 2 error is where we have given a false negative conclusion
where we have not rejected the null hypothesis but it is actually false.
So these are the type 1 and type 2 error that we have in hypothesis testing and these are
very basic concepts that we must, you know, consider while working with hypothesis testing
because this is quite significant and talking about the p value, it is nothing but a statistical
measurement that is going to valid data hypothesis against the observed data.
In simple terms, it basically tells you how likely it is that your data could have occurred
in the under the null hypothesis.
All right, so if it falls under the alpha value that is 0.05, then we can reject the null
hypothesis.
If it is more than that, then we accept or basically fail to reject null hypothesis.
Now, when I say fail or reject, let us say for example, if the p value is greater than
0.05 where we have taken the alpha value as 0.05 which means 95 percent certainty is the
probability that the null hypothesis is true and for a statistically significant test result,
p value has to be less than 0.05 which means the test hypothesis is false or should be
rejected.
And p value greater than 0.05 basically means that there was no effect that was observed
using that test.
And now that we know about all this, let us take a look at the first statistical test
that we have which is t test.
So t test is a parametric test that compares the means of two samples.
And ideally, a sample for the test t test should have less than 30 values that we were discussing
before.
And there are a few other assumptions also that we have to take before we can conduct the
t test.
So obviously, when you when you are conducting any statistical test, you have to make sure
that certain conditions are always met which basically means you have to check what kind
of data that is supported for this particular statistical test.
So the other assumptions that we have in t test are sample has to be independent that
is taken at random.
The homogeneity in the sample variances if we are taking two samples, the variance should
be equal.
And if those are not equal for unequal variances, we have a Welsh test, Welsh t test.
And the third assumption is the data is assumed to be normal.
It is distributed.
So we assume that the norm distribution is going to be normal.
So these are the three assumptions that we have for t test.
Now let's just take a look at what kind of t test are available for us.
So we have one sample, two sample and paired.
So for a one sample t test, we are comparing a sample against a standard value.
So let's say if I want to check for my sample, if the mean has changed or not, you know,
for a standard value, for example, let's say it was observed that the number of people
that passed their SATs in the last year were 50% of the people who appeared.
So that is a standard value that I have.
Now I want to check it on my sample that I've taken the 30 values if the sample is same
for those people or not.
So that is comparing the sample against a standard value.
So that comes under one sample t test.
And then we have two sample t test, of course, in which both the samples that we are comparing,
you know, the means of are coming from two different populations.
And if we take those two samples from the same population, then it becomes a paired t test.
These are the type of t test available to us.
And then again, the type of test that you are performing can be one tail or two tail.
So this is a very simple yet interesting concept over here, one tail and two tail.
Well, let's say if I want to check whether the population means a greater than or smaller
than the standard value in that one sample t test, I'll be using a one tail t test.
All right.
So if it gives me the value in the negative statistic, I will know that it is less than.
If it's in the positive size, I will know it is more than.
So that is why I will use one tail t test for a two tail t test.
I just want to check whether the population means differ significantly.
All right.
So we will just use the t test.
So the null hypothesis will be like both the sample means are equal.
The alternative one would be both the samples are not equal.
So that is how two tail and one tail t test works.
And computing the statistics for that is also really, we just have to divide the confidence
interval by two because we are using one tail and two tail t test.
All right.
So now let's just take a few examples and implement them using Python programming so that

So the first one is one sample t test.
Okay.
